speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: SCENE IV. The Tower of London.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Enter BUCKINGHAM, DERBY, HASTINGS, the BISHOP OF  ELY, RATCLIFF, LOVEL, with others, and take their seats at a table

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: My lords, at once: the cause why we are met

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Is, to determine of the coronation.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: In God's name, speak: when is the royal day?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Are all things fitting for that royal time?

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: It is, and wants but nomination.

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: To-morrow, then, I judge a happy day.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Who knows the lord protector's mind herein?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Who is most inward with the royal duke?

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: Your grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Who, I, my lord I we know each other's faces,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But for our hearts, he knows no more of mine,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Than I of yours;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Nor I no more of his, than you of mine.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I thank his grace, I know he loves me well;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But, for his purpose in the coronation.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I have not sounded him, nor he deliver'd

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: His gracious pleasure any way therein:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But you, my noble lords, may name the time;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And in the duke's behalf I'll give my voice,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Which, I presume, he'll take in gentle part.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: Now in good time, here comes the duke himself.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I have been long a sleeper; but, I hope,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My absence doth neglect no great designs,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which by my presence might have been concluded.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Had not you come upon your cue, my lord

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part,--

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I mean, your voice,--for crowning of the king.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His lordship knows me well, and loves me well.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I thank your grace.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My lord of Ely!

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: When I was last in Holborn,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I saw good strawberries in your garden there

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I do beseech you send for some of them.

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: Marry, and will, my lord, with all my heart.

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Drawing him aside

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our business,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And finds the testy gentleman so hot,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As he will lose his head ere give consent

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His master's son, as worshipful as he terms it,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Shall lose the royalty of England's throne.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Withdraw you hence, my lord, I'll follow you.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Exit GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM following

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: We have not yet set down this day of triumph.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: To-morrow, in mine opinion, is too sudden;

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: For I myself am not so well provided

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: As else I would be, were the day prolong'd.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Re-enter BISHOP OF ELY

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: Where is my lord protector? I have sent for these

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: strawberries.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: His grace looks cheerfully and smooth to-day;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: There's some conceit or other likes him well,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: When he doth bid good morrow with such a spirit.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I think there's never a man in Christendom

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: That can less hide his love or hate than he;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: For by his face straight shall you know his heart.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: What of his heart perceive you in his face

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: By any likelihood he show'd to-day?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Marry, that with no man here he is offended;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: For, were he, he had shown it in his looks.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: I pray God he be not, I say.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Re-enter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I pray you all, tell me what they deserve

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That do conspire my death with devilish plots

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Of damned witchcraft, and that have prevail'd

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Upon my body with their hellish charms?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: The tender love I bear your grace, my lord,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Makes me most forward in this noble presence

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: To doom the offenders, whatsoever they be

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I say, my lord, they have deserved death.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then be your eyes the witness of this ill:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: See how I am bewitch'd; behold mine arm

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is, like a blasted sapling, wither'd up:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And this is Edward's wife, that monstrous witch,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Consorted with that harlot strumpet Shore,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That by their witchcraft thus have marked me.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: If they have done this thing, my gracious lord--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If I thou protector of this damned strumpet--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Tellest thou me of 'ifs'?  Thou art a traitor:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Off with his head! Now, by Saint Paul I swear,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I will not dine until I see the same.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Lovel and Ratcliff, look that it be done:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The rest, that love me, rise and follow me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exeunt all but HASTINGS, RATCLIFF, and LOVEL

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Woe, woe for England! not a whit for me;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: For I, too fond, might have prevented this.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But I disdain'd it, and did scorn to fly:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Three times to-day my foot-cloth horse did stumble,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And startled, when he look'd upon the Tower,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: As loath to bear me to the slaughter-house.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: O, now I want the priest that spake to me:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I now repent I told the pursuivant

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: As 'twere triumphing at mine enemies,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: How they at Pomfret bloodily were butcher'd,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And I myself secure in grace and favour.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head!

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Dispatch, my lord; the duke would be at dinner:

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Make a short shrift; he longs to see your head.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: O momentary grace of mortal men,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Ready, with every nod, to tumble down

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Into the fatal bowels of the deep.

speaker: LOVEL
text_entry: Come, come, dispatch; 'tis bootless to exclaim.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: O bloody Richard! miserable England!

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I prophesy the fearful'st time to thee

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: That ever wretched age hath look'd upon.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Come, lead me to the block; bear him my head.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Exeunt
